title: Albanese meets with King Charles at Balmoral
text:
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has visited Balmoral Castle for a private meeting with King Charles III.

Albanese and fiance Jodie Haydon flew to Scotland overnight for the face-to-face visit, which the prime minister described as a privilege and a "great honour".

The King only two weeks ago praised the AUKUS defence pact between Australia, the US and Britain during Donald Trump's state visit to the UK.﻿

King Charles III during an audience with Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese at Balmoral Castle. (Getty)

The prime minister will tomorrow speak at the UK Labour Party conference in Liverpool before travelling to the United Arab Emirates.﻿

Earlier, Albanese joined the British Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer in discussing defence, security, trade and the economy.

Top of the agenda was how to protect the AUKUS pact from being unpicked by Donald Trump's America First agenda.

The US President's unique brand of populism has been matched in Britain by Nigel Farage's Reform party which is leading the UK polls.

Farage is riding a wave of anti-immigration sentiment helped along by rallies stoked by far-right activists .

March for Australia protests have also been held in major cities over the past few weeks.﻿

"That sends shivers through the spines on many of our communities," Starmer said.

"I don't want to see the rise of populist organisations," Albanese added.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Jodie Haydon arrives for an informal meeting with Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and Lady Victoria Starmer, the Prime Minister of Canada and Madam Diana Fox Carney and Mette Frederiksen, Prime Minister of Denmark at 10 Downing Street. (Dominic Lorrimer)

The British Prime Minister hosted his Australian counterpart at Number 10.

Albanese said: "We share values and today more so than ever really."

Later, he was seen heading into the famous door with some Aussie-brewed beers with partner Haydon.

He clutched a four-pack of his own Albo brew by Willie The Boatman﻿ in Sydney.

READ MORE: Man dies after plane owned by skydiving business crashes

British Prime Minister Keir Starmer (L) welcomes Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese to 10 Downing Street. (Getty)

Albanese and Starmer are both from the progressive side of politics.

Albanese scored a thumping re-election in May.

The other is facing an early reckoning just 14 months after winning power.

The British public is increasingly concerned about illegal migrants, with many crossing the English Channel in boats.

The British PM has announced a mandatory digital ID in a bid to stamp out illegal workers.

title: Egyptian wrestler pulls 700-ton ship with his teeth
text:
With nothing but grit, muscle and an iron jaw, a hugely popular Egyptian wrestler geared up for an extraordinary challenge yesterday: pulling a 700-ton ship across the water with a rope held only by his teeth.

“Today, I have come to break the world record,” Ashraf Mahrous said in an interview in Egypt’s Red Sea resort of Hurghada after the challenge.

It was no easy task but Ashraf Mahrous, also known by his nickname Kabonga, has dazzled before with his astonishing strength. Earlier this year, he pulled a train. He has also singlehandedly pulled a locomotive and four years ago, a truck.

Mahrous in action whilst a Guinness Book of World Records official watches on. (AP)

With each achievement, his popularity has soared — children run after him in the streets, where he's known simply as “strong man.”

With the ship pull, Mahrous, a 44-year-old native of the port city of Ismalia, hopes to get yet another recognition from the Guinness World Records.

A triumph by the Red Sea

The scene was set at the shore in Hurghada. Mahrous first pulled a 700-ton ship, and to affirm his challenge he pulled two ships weighing approximately 1150 tons together.

“I pulled them both, thanks to God, to prove to my friends and the whole world that God blessed me by being the strongest man in the world,” Mahrous said.

He said the current Guinness World Record is a 614-ton ship set in 2018.

Mahrous said he will send videos and photos of his attempt to Guinness World Records to be evaluated.

Mahrous celebrating his feat. (AP)

In preparation for the feat, Mahrous followed a protein- and iron-rich diet, consuming at least a dozen eggs, two whole chickens, and 5 kilograms of fish every day — all while training for two hours, three times a day.

It wasn't his first ship pull. Six years ago, he tried for two hours before he managed to pull a 4000-ton ship in the water, a rope strapped to his shoulders, for about 30 metres. The event was caught on video.

″I grunted and yelled as I pulled the ship, and I spoke to it, saying ‘It’s either me or you today,’" he told The Associated Press recently at his local gym in Cairo, where he trains daily.

Mahrous believes that speaking with the object he pulls beforehand helps him establish a connection and is key to his success. “It’s important for me to treat the object that I will pull as part of my body that moves along with my heart beat,” he said.

An extraordinary child

Mahrous, 190 centimetres tall and weighing 155 kilograms, said his strength emerged early.

As a child, he would carry his friends for fun and haul heavy loads, several gas cylinders at once on a wheelbarrow. He was nine when his father lost his job as a contractor in Iraq and after that, Mahrous began knocking on doors, offering to lift heavy items for some cash.

Once, he accidentally broke a friend’s arm when he tried to pull him as they played. He helped people move bricks, sandbags and other heavy materials — and he was fast. He loved sports and trained in kung fu, kickboxing and even established a wrestling team in Cairo.

It was only when his friends saw him easily flip giant tires 10 times in a row in a deserted courtyard at their gym and push a car using only a finger that they encouraged him to go for a world record.

“I was inspired by people who broke records and felt like they are no better than me,” he said. Now he's less fearful of injuries and more concerned about failing to accomplish a pull.

Mahrous was supported by a crowd of people on the shores of the Red Sea. (AP)

Past recognitions

In March, he was formally recognised by Guinness World Records for the heaviest rail pull: He pulled a train weighing 279 tons with a rope held by his teeth for a distance of nearly 10 metres. At the time, he received two other certificates, for the heaviest locomotive pull and for the fastest 100-metre road vehicle pull.

Mahrous, who is also president of the Egyptian Federation for Professional Wrestlers, was previously recognised by Guinness in June 2021, for pulling a 15,730-kilogram truck with his teeth. And in February 2024, the international franchise recognised him for cracking and eating 11 raw eggs in 30 seconds.

He wears a mouthguard during pulling events but says he has no concerns about his teeth. Instead of going to a dentist, he uses a miswak — a traditional teeth-cleaning twig rich in anti-bacterial compounds that help prevent decay.

He says he takes no supplements but eats, sleeps and works out at least twice every day.

His ambitions are far from over. Next, he plans to send a request to the Egyptian presidency for permission to pull a 263,000-ton submarine.

He also hopes someday to pull a plane using only his eyelid muscles.

title: Real estate agent buys cut-price home of retiree with Alzheimer's
text:
A real estate agent who believed she was doing the "right thing" by buying a vulnerable retiree's property at $500,000 below market value has had her licence suspended.

Rachelle Carmen Nohra took advantage of the 82-year-old with alcohol problems and symptoms of Alzheimer's by purchasing his Sydney home for $600,000.

She offered this price despite knowing his property had a similar value to one sold next door for $1.1 million.

Nohra, who is the director of Eser Property in Greystanes, purchased the man's home at a "significant undervalue" in a personal capacity in April 2023, a tribunal decision published yesterday revealed.

She promised that the retiree - known for legal reasons as Mr A - could remain living at the property for the rest of his life.

However, their subsequent tenancy agreement allowed him to be evicted with 90 days' notice, the NSW Civil and Administrative Tribunal found.

Nohra did not appear to understand there was a conflict between her own interests and the retiree's when she bought his property or that he was vulnerable to be taken advantage of, the tribunal said.

"(Her) lack of insight into such basic matters is of serious concern to the tribunal," senior member Lachlan Bryant wrote.

Nohra had approached the tribunal seeking to overturn a decision by the Commissioner for Fair Trading suspending her licence for a year, imposing a $11,000 fine and directing her to undertake further training.

She contended that she was still a "fit and proper person" to act as a real estate agent.

Instead, Bryant found she had taken advantage of the 82-year-old by purchasing his property without giving him the chance to get financial or legal advice.

"Subject to the costs of the sale, the applicant stood to gain a windfall from the sale of around $500,000, on her own estimates, and upon its completion was enriched to (the retiree's) detriment," he wrote.

Her actions were "sufficiently closely connected to her profession" to warrant reprimand and punishment, the tribunal found.

"(Nohra's) belief that purchasing (his) property in the circumstances was the right thing to do is of serious concern," Bryant said.

"(Her) conduct may put the real estate industry into disrepute and falls short of the community's expectations of a licence holder."

She had failed to repay further money to the retiree or take steps to ensure his tenancy at the property was secure over the long-term, Bryant noted.

However, he declined to impose a higher penalty sought by Fair Trading - including cancelling her licence completely and banning her from acting as a real estate agent for three years.

That was "too harsh", he found.

title: Retro gadgets stand test of time in an era of disposable tech
text:
Ron Coald has loved film since he was young and has amassed a significant collection since then.

"I used to collect old movie film from the projector box in the Katanning cinema," he said.

"It built up from that; I bought my first camera when I was a schoolboy."

The community's love of old appliances is keeping an Albany repairer busy. (ABC Great Southern: Rosemary Murphy)

At his home in Albany on WA's south coast, his collection of all things film contains cameras, film and players from throughout the ages.

"I've still got a H16 16-millimetre … it's a magic looking camera and I used to cover the Avon Descent with that," he said.

"I've also got the first video camera that came in; you had the camera in your hand, and on your shoulder you had the recording part of it."

The equipment, however, requires some upkeep.

And that's where Neil Harrison comes in.

Sentimental value

Neil Harrison says televisions are a common items for repair. (ABC Great Southern: Rosemary Murphy)

The Albany repairer is kept busy with jobs from people like Mr Coald who are choosing to get their older electrical appliances fixed rather than throwing them out and buying new.

"We mainly used to concentrate on audio-visual gear, but we're finding there's a lot of other stuff out there that does require repair," Mr Harrison said.

"Sometimes it's sentimental value, sometimes it used to work well and people want it to work well again."

Neil Harrison says older electrical equipment was made to be fixed. (ABC Great Southern: Rosemary Murphy)

He has worked on some interesting audio systems.

"The old radiograms from the 40s, perhaps 50s, 60s and so forth — a lot that's been handed down and it was their parents or grandparents," Mr Harrison said.

" Vinyl … records have made a miraculous comeback, so we're doing a lot of that repair."

Ron Coald's collection ranges from stereoscopes through to DVDs and video cassette players. (ABC Great Southern: Rosemary Murphy)

Made for repair

Mr Harrison said there was a difference between older electrical gear and more modern equipment.

"The older stuff was always designed to be repaired and designed to be repaired at component level," he said.

"Modern electronics, sometimes that can be done, but most of the time it's almost like replacing circuit boards.

"Everything has become very miniaturised, surface mounted, and it can be a little bit tricky to actually repair at component level."

Elaine Johnson continues to use a mixer she bought in the 1970s. (Supplied: Rebecca Johnson)

At Quairading in WA's Wheatbelt, Elaine Johnson's kitchen holds evidence that old electronics were made to last.

She still uses the electric mixer she purchased shortly after she was married in 1972.

"I was a young police woman on duty in the Hay Street Mall and I saw it being demonstrated," Ms Johnson said.

" It's still going strong and I've used it for lots of catering for CWA. "

title: Canberra car dealers and public servants by day, pro wrestlers by night
text:
By day, public servant Del Goncalves works in a typical office and wears typical office clothes, but come nightfall, she dons a bunny costume and trades her office for a wrestling ring.

She's among a growing cohort of Canberrans who have fallen in love with pro wrestling — a sport where pain and injury are a given.

"I always get asked if it hurts — it does," Ms Goncalves said.

" Being someone who couldn't even throw a ball … it was a big surprise how much I fell in love with this. "

Wrestling competitions are now happening in Canberra as the sport grows in popularity. (Supplied: Dan Dwyer)

Popularised by the likes of Hulk Hogan, John Cena, and Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, pro wrestlers rehearse choreographed stunts before performing matches against opponents for live audiences.

Though the sport has a small base in Australia, it has developed a cult following in Canberra after the launch of a local wrestling academy and the Slam! Pro Wrestling league.

Joining the academy after watching a local show in 2022, Ms Goncalves said the sport was about testing her limits, putting on a show and taking on an alter ego.

Del Goncalves says wrestling has given her a new sense of confidence. (ABC News: Emily Anderson)

"During the day I'm quite an introverted person … but once I get into the ring and I go from Del to Moshpit Bunny," she said.

"All of a sudden loud, I'm larger than life, I've got confidence that daytime me doesn't have."

An appetite for a fight

The sport's popularity in Canberra has come as a surprise for academy co-founder Dan Dwyer who, when he isn't in the ring, works as a car salesman.

Dan Dwyer goes by the stage name Dan Archer when he's competing. (Supplied)

"You'll see me in a nice suit or polo pants," Mr Dwyer said.

"[Then] Saturday rolls around and we're into the tights and the big gold belts.

" I think the haircut and the gigantic muscles gives it away a little bit. "

Known by his stage name Dan Archer, the Canberra man began wrestling when he was 16 years old after being inspired by video games and World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE).

Since then, he has competed around Australia, but said he wanted to create a local championship to support local and national talent.

"I'd often find myself travelling up and down the highways to Sydney and parts of New South Wales to be able to wrestle in front of audience," Mr Dwyer said.

"But now [Canberra] has become quite a hotbed where we've got people travelling from all around the country."

Canberra car salesman Dan Dwyer in character as Dan Archer for pro wrestling. (ABC News: Mark Moore)

The wrestling performances have drawn crowds of up to 2,400, which Mr Dwyer said was the largest he's experienced for an all-Australian event.

He said it's the atmosphere of the crowd that hooks people in.

"You've got hundreds of people cheering for you or booing for you wanting to see you get hurt or see you succeed," Mr Dwyer said.

"There's no other feeling you can get from other sports or hobbies."

Battered and bruised

Though athletes practice moves hundreds of times before taking them to the performance stage, injuries are part and parcel of wrestling.

It's something childhood educator Mia Fisher found out the hard way 18 months ago during a match against a fellow Canberra wrestler.

Mia Fisher didn't notice her injury until she'd left the arena and the adrenaline had started to wear off. (ABC News: Emily Anderson)

"Adrenaline is a wonderful thing. The match got called, I grabbed my arm, I straightened it out and I went out the back and I said, 'I broke my arm'," Ms Fisher said.

Nine months, two titanium plates and 13 screws later, her character "Kitten Mask" returned to the stage.

"I love how you constantly put your body on the line to entertain an audience," Ms Fisher said.

Thousands attended the wrestling competition in Canberra. (ABC News: Emily Anderson)

Despite the injury, she said wrestling is a hobby that she wants to continue doing for the rest of her life and hopes that she can inspire generations to take on the ring.

"I like to think I have little kids looking up at me and thinking maybe they could do that one day too," she said.

"I'm so grateful that I get to perform in front of all these people."

title: Lions show why they're the complete team with second straight flag
text:
The age-old adage is a team of champions will beat a champion team.

Often, we get seduced by the stars of the game, those referred to in mononyms.

Think Buddy, Nat, Danger, Harley, Bont or Trac.

The Lions have broken the other way.

They are the complete team, with contributors across the board. For the second straight year, they have come together as more than the sum of their parts to tear a seemingly competitive grand final to shreds.

"I think in the fullness of time, when you sort of sit back and you think about the quality of team that beat us in this grand final, it might ease the pain a little bit," Geelong coach Chris Scott said after the match.

The 2025 Lions were a slightly different beast to the side from last year. Their centrepiece forward, Joe Daniher, walked off into the sunset after winning his elusive flag.

Geelong's superpower fails its biggest test Photo shows Jeremy Cameron crouched and nursing an arm injury during the Cats' AFL grand final against the Lions. It is the cruel irony of sport that what is usually the ace up Geelong's sleeve proved to be its downfall in the loss to the Brisbane Lions in the season decider.

One of their most important defenders, Jack Payne, was ruled out early in the year. Their established tall forward, Eric Hipwood, was sidelined on the cusp of finals after playing most of the year with a partially torn ACL.

Other key contributors, such as Jarrod Berry, Lincoln McCarthy, Keidean Coleman and Noah Answerth, missed the biggest game of the year.

The Lions fielded six players in the 2025 grand final that did not touch the field in last year's triumph over Sydney.

Oscar McInerney cruelly missed out on last year's success after dislocating his shoulder the week before. Levi Ashcroft saw his brother be feted across the nation while he waited in the wings at the ground.

All six — McInerney, Ashcroft, Bruce Reville, Sam Marshall, Ty Gallop and Darcy Gardiner — stood up when it mattered most on Saturday.

How Lions' win unfolded

Like many grand finals, the early going was a slog, a physical test of wills.

The first six minutes and 30 seconds saw 15 stoppages. Both sides looked unwilling to take risks.

Suggesting it was a cagey start would be an understatement. The Lions wasted some chances on goal early, while the Cats did not make the most of their significant territorial advantage.

Often this type of start is the first step of a classic to come. At half-time everything was level. Not just the scores at 36 apiece, but also the kicks and handballs were dead level.

However, the inside 50s and clearances slightly leaned to the Lions.

There was a clue to what would happen in the match later on.

Geelong was committed to forcing the ball to the wings in the first quarter, actively avoiding the middle of the ground.

The Cats were throwing defenders on the edges of the corridor, forcing the Lions to either take risks inboard or to safely kick the ball boundary-side. This took much of the pace out of the contest for both sides, and forced it into Geelong's preferred intercept-heavy game.

This all changed in the second quarter. The Lions took the game on more through the middle and enjoyed some success. This stretched Geelong's defence out and allowed other avenues to goal as the match progressed.

The Lions only had one disposal in the centre square when transitioning the ball from defence in the first quarter.

They managed 15 more across the rest of the match, with the balance happening in the second and third quarters. The Cats only used the corridor out of defence once across the match.

But the pay-off on the scoreboard was not immediate, and the teams went into half-time all locked up, the first time a grand final had been level at half-time since 1909.

Something entirely different unfolded, though, after the long break.

The visitors from up north heralded a scoring procession in the second half, one that rivalled the Demons in the 2021 season decider.

The Lions kicked nine goals to one to set the match alight and crush Geelong's hopes.

The insertion of inspirational co-captain Lachie Neale also changed the tone of the grand final. Suddenly, the Lions' strong clearance game picked up, leaving the Cats with more questions than answers.

The Lions won the clearance count by 15 in the second half and made that difference count on the scoreboard as well.

The Cats outscored the Lions from clearances 108 to 65 in their previous three encounters this season.

The Lions flipped the script in the grand final, outscoring the Cats 73 to 29 points. With the final margin being 47 points, those 44 hard-won points were the big difference in the match.

Where in the first half there had been no space to operate for either side, the Lions found plenty. They found targets streaming into space every time they went forward.

Charlie Cameron, deployed in his old role of deepest forward, had a field day with the impeccable supply from those higher up the ground. He finished with four goals, his most productive return since round 10 in 2024.

The Lions locked the ball in their front half of the ground after half-time, with the game being played on their territory.

The Cats could not capitalise when they occasionally managed a foray forward, with their attacking worries exacerbated by the injury sustained by Coleman medallist Jeremy Cameron.

Patrick Dangerfield said he heard Cameron's arm crack in the incident.

By the time the Cats kicked their second goal of the second half, the grand final was all but over.

Ashcroft claims second 'Norm'

There have only been five winners of more than one Norm Smith Medal, with the exclusive club growing on Saturday.

Will Ashcroft joined Andrew McLeod, Gary Ayres, Dustin Martin and Luke Hodge in winning at least two Norm Smith Medals as best on ground in a grand final.

Ashcroft, 21, has long been considered one of the best young players in the game. The word "young" can now be removed from that description.

The Queenslander has established himself as one of the finest big-game players of the current era. He is the youngest to win two Norm Smith Medals in the award's storied history.

Ashcroft was everywhere in the victory. He managed career-high figures in clearances, inside 50s, tackles and metres gained.

He not only won the hard ball for the Lions, but also moved it forward dangerously while defending with aplomb.

Ashcroft wins Norm Smith Medal Photo shows Will Ashcroft poses with his Norm Smith Medal and AFL premiership medal. Will Ashcroft claims back-to-back Norm Smith Medals after playing a starring role in the Brisbane Lions' grand final win over Geelong.

"From top to bottom, everyone puts in so much work. We keep turning up and battling through adversity," Ashcroft said during the medal presentation.

Ashcroft was far from a lone hand for the Lions.

Co-captain Harris Andrews produced one of the finest displays of his career, controlling the match from down back.

He acted as a one-man aerial defence system, with five intercept marks forcing the Cats to avoid his part of the ground.

Hugh McCluggage also had a day out, gaining more territory than he did in any other match this year. The Allansford product kicked four goals while also providing excellent delivery by foot.

'A bitter pill to swallow'

As ecstatic as the Lions and the city of Brisbane are now, those down the M1 in Geelong will be disappointed.

The Cats managed to make the grand final, despite the chips being against them at different stages of the season.

"To be perfectly frank, there were times [this season] where it just seemed unlikely that we would be able to overcome those obstacles to give ourselves a chance today," Scott said.

"Even without those things, I'd still be really proud of the way our club and our players in particular just keep fronting up.

"(It) Is a bitter pill to swallow because I think we'd shown that our best footy was going to challenge anyone."

The Cats will have the off-season to reflect on their loss to the Lions. (AAP: Joel Carrett)

The Cats will be there or thereabouts next year, as they always tend to be.

Brisbane's future looks as bright as it did after last year.

The Lions are expected to have another highly rated Academy product, Daniel Annable, join the club in the draft.

They are set to add Sam Draper and Oscar Allen to their tall stocks, strengthening their list even further.

But for now, the focus is on celebrating their hard-earned achievement before looking at doing it again.

title: Albanese coy on critical minerals offer ahead of meeting with Trump
text:
Anthony Albanese won't divulge whether he will take an offering to his long-awaited one-on-one meeting with Donald Trump next month, like other world leaders, but flagged that there will be upcoming negotiations over access to Australia's critical minerals stockpiles.

The government had previously signalled plans to ramp up the mining and processing of the valuable critical minerals, with the hope it could be leveraged to negotiate exemptions from the Trump administration's trade tariffs.

But on Sunday, the prime minister would not say exactly what Australia's critical minerals offer to the United States included — nor whether it was exclusive to the Trump administration, after he discussed the issue with his British counterpart.

Other world leaders have gone into their meetings with Mr Trump armed with a significant gesture. British Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer, for example, went bearing an invitation from the king for a state visit.

"We will have those negotiations with President Trump in person," Mr Albanese told ABC's Insiders on Sunday.

King Charles and Anthony Albanese during a royal audience engagement at Balmoral Castle. (Supplied: Instagram / @Albomp)

"Australia has everything that is in demand, almost the entire periodic table, and whether you're looking at lithium, with the reserves that we have, or cobalt, or copper, or vanadium, we have great resources."

Critical minerals could end up being part of the AUKUS deal with the US and UK, Mr Albanese said, because the minerals will be required to build defence equipment.

"One of the things that we want to do is to make sure that we don't just dig things up, our resources, export them, watch someone else value-add, and then import them back at greater prices," he said.

"What we're talking about here is not giving anything to anyone — even our friends. What we are talking about is making sure that we maximise the return to Australia of that."

After a "splendid" lunch with King Charles at Balmoral Castle in Scotland, Mr Albanese also ruled out holding a referendum to make Australia a republic while he is in office.

"I have made it clear that I wanted to hold one referendum while I was PM and we did that … so one referendum the entire time you are prime minister, we did that," he said.

Albanese to sit down with Trump next month

The prime minister is scheduled to sit down for his first formal meeting with Mr Trump on October 20, after an earlier attempt on the sidelines of the G20 summit fell over when the president departed early amid the conflict with Iran.

The pair then had a brief catch-up during a function for world leaders in New York last week, with a smiling selfie from the encounter posted to social media.

But off the back of the meet and greet, Mr Albanese was coy on what would be discussed when he returns to the US.

"I need to treat him with the respect that the president of the United States deserves, and I expect that to be returned," he said.

Donald Trump imposes 100 per cent tariff on pharmaceuticals from October 1 Photo shows Prescription medicines The United States will impose a 100 per cent tariff on imports of branded or patented pharmaceutical products from October 1, unless a pharmaceutical company is building a manufacturing plant in the US.

"And certainly, the indications are — we've had five either phone conversations or greetings in person now — and they've all been warm, constructive, positive and optimistic."

He also would not offer his views on Mr Trump's address to the United Nations, in which he urged European nations to follow his lead in cracking down on migration and told leaders, "your countries are going to hell".

"It's not my job to give a critique of other leaders. My job is to govern in Australia's national interest. And part of what we've done is to be strong on borders without being weak on humanity," he said.

"The truth is, that around the world, including in Australia, people want borders to be controlled. They want control over their migration system.

"That's a way that you build support for migration as well."

The Coalition has accused the prime minister of dropping the ball by failing to meet with the president sooner, and blamed the government for failing to negotiate an exemption to the Trump administration's worldwide trade tariffs.

"I want to know what Mr Albanese is going to be doing in relation to that, to secure something better for Australians and protect Australian jobs," Shadow Foreign Affairs Minister Michaelia Cash told Sky News on Sunday.

"The relationship in Washington is not strong, and because it's not strong, Mr Albanese is not able to pick up the phone, like other world leaders are able to do, and speak directly to the US president about the impact of his announcements on Australia."

Mr Trump on Thursday announced a 100 per cent tariff on imports of branded or patented pharmaceutical products from October 1, unless a pharmaceutical company is building a manufacturing plant in the US.

Pharmaceutical products are one of the top export markets for Australia to the US, worth about $1.6 billion in 2023-24.

title: Big barra comp kicks off as leaders seek lake restocking solution
text:
On every menu in the town of Kununurra, 3,200 kilometres north of Perth, you will find barramundi, and in every store, you will find fishing supplies.

Fishing is the lifeblood of the remote Kimberley town and is put on show every year with the Barra Bash competition.

The event is Western Australia's largest recreational fishing competition, with more than 1,200 registrations on the first day of this week's event.

Decades of barramundi stocking at Lake Kununurra has led to increased fish sizes. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

Keen anglers have four days to reel in the biggest barramundi across the catchment zone, with last year's winning catch coming in at 1.4 metres.

Competitors are hoping to trump that, with predictions this year's event could see barramundi exceeding 1.5m.

As the wet season approaches, temperatures routinely push 40 degrees Celsius, and according to event organiser Aaron Macnamara, the barramundi are biting.

"The only tip I can say is, you gotta be in it to win it," he said.

" If you don't have your line in the water, you've got no chance. "

Aaron Macnamara says the barramundi are biting. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

Why such big barra?

When part of the upper Ord River was separated into a man-made freshwater reservoir called Lake Kununurra in 1963, fish migration paths were disrupted and fish stocks gradually declined.

A grassroots campaign in the late 1990s and the newly formed Lake Kununurra Fish Stock Enhancement Group drove plans to reintroduce barramundi into the ecosystem, with hopes recreational fishing would benefit the town.

Juvenile barramundi, known as fingerlings, were bred and introduced into the lake, where the rich environment of warm temperatures and an abundance of food aid rapid fish growth.

Some anglers say the East Kimberley is Australia's premier barramundi fishing region. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

One million juveniles have been introduced into Lake Kununurra in the past decade.

But the state government cut funding for the fish restocking program in 2023, when Broome's North Regional TAFE aquaculture program and the hatchery which grew the fingerlings shut down.

Lake Kununurra Barramundi Restocking Group head Damien Thomas said Lake Kununurra had not been restocked since then, raising concerns about the long-term future of fishing.

Damien Thomas wants to see the restocking program relaunched. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

He said the remoteness of the area made sustaining the restocking program challenging.

"The Kimberley's twice the size of Victoria, and there's only 40,000 people here, so it's very remote," he said.

"We're just volunteers — we don't have the money stick or the bank account, so really the money's got to come through a joint venture through RecFishWest and the state government."

Seeking a stocking solution

In August, seafood giant Tassal launched a new hatchery in Broome, using it to stock its farm north of Derby.

RecFishWest chief executive Andrew Rowland said he had been speaking with Tassal about supporting barramundi restocking at Lake Kununurra.

"They're [Tassal] not quite ready to scale up to support the program at this point, but have noted they will be likely to have that conversation in the future," he said.

Andrew Rowland wants more state government funding for barramundi stocking. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

Tassal corporate affairs manager Tom Middleton told the ABC in August that the company would be "really excited" to come on board with the program, but that it would require a "team effort" from government and stakeholders.

Mr Rowland said he had been looking further afield to secure a barramundi supply.

"We know there's an opportunity to supply barramundi fingerlings out of the Northern Territory, there's a couple of hatcheries there, and we know that the government's gone and had a chat to them, but we are still none too wiser about the results of what's next," he said.

WA Fisheries Minister Jackie Jarvis said in a statement the Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development would continue to work with RecFishWest and aquaculture bodies to explore ongoing support of the stocking program.

Australia's Barra-dise?

Shire of Wyndham-East Kimberley planning and management director Nick Allen said the East Kimberley was a top fishing destination and the solitude the area offered was like nowhere else.

Nick Allen promotes East Kimberley fishing. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

"Here you can go out and spend three or four days and not see a single boat or camp on a riverbank and not see anyone," he said.

"The quality of fish on offer here is fantastic.

title: Australia's top rail journeys for tourists wanting to take it all in
text:
Far from the hustle and bustle of the daily commute, Australia's luxury rail journeys take a different, more romantic track.

It is rail to be enjoyed rather than tolerated: savoured for the trip itself rather than endured between one appointment and the next.

Some of these train adventures are living artefacts which transport their passengers back in time as they shuttle from one heritage station to the next.

Others are the cross-country equivalent of a luxury ocean cruise, complete with fine dining.

The Great Southern operates across four states. (Supplied: Stephen Whitaker, Trains Camera Action)

Self-styled rail fan Stephen Whitaker said rail tourism offered a gentle, relaxed and underrated alternative to air travel for those in no particular hurry to get anywhere.

"I think the idea of train travel stems back to a time when we weren't necessarily rushed to get to places," he said.

"There was more of an adventure in what we were doing.

"People refer to it as the romantic period of rail when you had steam trains and the idea of going from Melbourne to Cairns, from a time when the world was less connected."

Stephen Whitaker is self-confessed train fan. (Supplied: Stephen Whitaker)

Mr Whitaker said the social aspect of rail travel was sometimes overlooked by travellers who jetted from one place to the next.

"It's always been a mode of transport that's very social.

"In part, that's because you can move around. It's harder to move around an aeroplane and impossible in a car or a coach.

" You add things like dining carriages and lounge cars and it takes it to a whole new level. "

The platinum-level sleeping accommodation offered by the Indian Pacific and The Ghan. (Supplied: Journey Beyond Rail)

Blast from the past

Mr Whitaker said rail fans, or trainspotters, had an affection for all forms of rail transport, even the humble suburban commuter types.

"Don't get me wrong, my friends and I regularly [ride the commuter network] … and you can find a level of enjoyment," he said.

However, rail for pleasure, whether heritage rail or luxury rail, remained his passion and the predominant interest among his network of rail fans.

"Almost every state has heritage railways.

"Commonly, they're run by a bunch of volunteers who've managed to acquire an old steam or diesel locomotive from the railways, spend all their time restoring it and then running it for the joy of it.

Part of the appeal of the Pichi Richi Railway is its diverse fleet of locomotives. (Supplied: Kane Stevenson, Kane's Trains)

"Some of these run on the main lines, but then you have dedicated heritage groups that have their own tracks. Puffing Billy is a perfect example of that where they run 13.5 kilometres of their own track."

Then there is the appeal of long-distance rail like The Ghan or the Indian Pacific, both operated by Journey Beyond Rail.

The Indian Pacific is considered a sister train of The Ghan. (Supplied: Railfan Network)

"I think there was a period in Australia where railway companies thought they could compete with air travel, and the reality is you can't really have a train going 800 kilometres per hour," Mr Whitaker said.

" If you look at The Ghan or the Indian Pacific, it's a total experience. It's your hotel, it's your restaurant and it's also your mode of travel. "

Nannette Holliday thinks travel is better on a train than a plane — if you have the time. (Supplied: Nannette Holliday)

First-class travel

Freelance international travel writer Nannette Holliday said luxury rail was back in fashion as an alternative to air travel, with most passages booked out well in advance.

She said Australia's long-distance services were a match for any of the world's great rail journeys.

"Last year, when I went on the Eastern and Oriental Express when it started up again from Singapore to Malaysia, I compared it with The Ghan," Ms Holliday said.

"The Ghan, the Indian Pacific, the Great Southern: each is a different experience, and you learn about the regions you travel through, not just through the sights and the stops, but also the food and wine you have on board.

Luxury rail services such as The Ghan feature on-board dining. (Supplied: Journey Beyond Rail)

"If you have a week or so up your sleeve and you want to relax, you are much better off [on a train than a plane].

"You could be sitting on a train, looking out at the landscape passing by as you are holding a sparkling wine in your hand, chatting to the new friends you have made. It's hard to find anything else like that in Australia."

Stephen Whitaker's guide to Australia's great railway rides

Indian Pacific

Australia's longest rail service by distance is the mighty Indian Pacific. (Supplied: Stephen Whitaker, Trains Camera Action)

"Potentially the most well-known long-distance train in Australia, the Indian Pacific spans the width of Australia, running from Sydney in the east to Perth in the west, with a stop in Adelaide. There's so much to see on this trip, from the run through the Blue Mountains to the wide, open plains of central Australia."

The Ghan

The Ghan is arguably Australia's most famous train. (Supplied: Kane Stevenson, Kane's Trains)

"Often thought of as the sister train to the Indian Pacific, The Ghan runs the length of Australia, from Adelaide in the south to Darwin in the north. Running outside the tropical-north wet season, the train is one of contrasts, taking you from the fertile south, through the arid centre, including a stop in Alice Springs, to the tropical north."

Great Southern

The Great Southern operates between Brisbane and Adelaide. (Supplied: Stephen Whitaker, Trains Camera Action)

"My favourite train in Australia, by far, is the Great Southern. It only operates over 10 to 12 weeks in summer and is the only passenger train to operate across four states, between Brisbane and Adelaide. This means you'll see all kinds of Australian scenery, from the beaches near Coffs Harbour, the Adelaide Hills and the bright lights of Sydney and Melbourne."

Puffing Billy

Puffing Billy Railway was built in 1900 and is a major tourist attraction. (Supplied: Puffing Billy Railway)

"Probably one of the best known and resourced heritage tourist railways in Australia. It provides a 13.5km journey along dedicated heritage railway through scenic Victorian countryside."

Steamrail Victoria

Steamrail Victoria's A2 986 locomotive in outer suburban Melbourne. (Supplied: Anthony Evans, Railtown Productions)

"Steamrail Victoria operates regular heritage steam, diesel and electric trains across the Victorian rail network. The breadth and quality of its fleet is a credit to this volunteer organisation."

Transport Heritage NSW

Locomotive pair 3265 Hunter and 3526 Nanny hard at work between Tamworth and Armidale. (Supplied: Anthony Evans, Railtown Productions)

"One of the best government-supported heritage programs, operating regular tours throughout the Sydney area."

Vintage Rail Journeys

Vintage Rail Journeys visits part of the mainline network not usually accessible to passenger trains. (Supplied: Stephen Whitaker, Trains Camera Action)

"Operates regular multi-day tours across regional New South Wales on a restored set of Southern Aurora carriages (the train that used to run between Sydney and Melbourne), hauled by heritage diesel locomotives."

Kuranda Scenic Railway

A Kuranda Scenic Railway train passing through the Great Dividing Range. (Supplied: Stephen Whitaker, Trains Camera Action)

"Arguably the most scenic railway in Australia, the trip from Cairns to Kuranda ascends the Great Dividing Range through the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area. The line is over 100 years old and includes many bridges and tunnels."

XPT

The XPT crossing the Nambucca River near Coffs Harbour. (Supplied: Stephen Whitaker, Trains Camera Action)

"The XPT (Express Passenger Train) services the regional NSW network, travelling as far as Brisbane and Melbourne. These are regular regional services but offer on-train sleeping accommodation."

The Overland

The Overland travels the 828km line between Melbourne and Adelaide. (Supplied: Railfan Network)

"The Overland runs once a week in each direction between Melbourne and Adelaide and offers the ability to travel on an all-daylight train between the two cities."

Pichi Richi Railway

The Pichi Richi heritage train in outback South Australia. (Supplied: Kane Stevenson, Kane's Trains)

"The Pichi Richi Railway operates regular steam train services along part of the original Ghan route between Port Augusta and Quorn in South Australia. The railway has an extensive fleet of locomotives and rolling stock."

Spirit Of Queensland

The Spirit of Queensland covers the 1,600km trip from Brisbane to Cairns. (Supplied: Stephen Whitaker, Trains Camera Action)

"The replacement for the famous Sunlander, operating between Brisbane and Cairns. It is formed by a Diesel Tilt Train which can reach speeds of 160kph. A ride on the Spirit of Queensland is a great way to see the variety of coastal cities and towns."

Inlander/Westlander/Spirit Of The Outback

The Westlander is operated by Queensland Rail on its Main and Western lines. (Supplied: Stephen Whitaker, Trains Camera Action)

"Other long-distance services operated by Queensland Rail. The Inlander runs the 977km between Townsville and Mount Isa, the Westlander tracks the 777km between Brisbane and Charleville, while the Spirit of the Outback travels 1,325km between Brisbane and Longreach."

Gulflander/Savannahlander

The Gulflander operates between Normanton and Croydon. (Supplied: Stephen Whitaker, Trains Camera Action)

"The Gulflander is billed as a journey from 'nowhere to nowhere'. These two similar services tour north Queensland's Gulf and Savannah country."

West Coast Wilderness Railway

West Coast Wilderness Railway's Abt locomotive. (Supplied: Mikhala Graham, Railfan Network)

"A uniquely Tasmanian heritage experience through the stunning Tasmanian World Heritage Wilderness Area."

title: No more streaming fees, these films and TV series are free to watch
text:
Last year Aussies spent on average $63 per month on streaming services, according to Deloitte's Media and Entertainment Consumer Insights report.

In the months since that report dropped, streamers Apple+, Netflix, Stan, Kayo and Disney+ have all hit subscribers with a fee hike.

But there is a better way.

There is a whole treasure trove of film and TV streaming right now that you can access FOR FREE — if you know where to look.

We've done the hard yards, sifting through three free Australian streaming services — iview, SBSonDemand and Brollie — to bring you the cream of the crop.

Family

Looney Tunes Back in Action The human and cartoon characters in Looney Tunes: Back in Action ( ) Watching this wacky live-action/animation 20 years from its release date is a wildly entertaining experience. Carrying the spirit of Who Framed Roger Rabbit, get ready to see peak action hero-era Brendan Fraser as a flailing stuntman paired with Bugs and Daffy to save the world from money-grubbing ACME CEO Mr Chairman (Steve Martin at peak silliness). None of it makes a huge amount of sense but that's the beauty of Looney Tunes! Back in Action is a goofy, absurd and wonderfully funny way to spend an afternoon. Trailer Where to watch: iview Paddington & Paddington 2 British actor Ben Whishaw provides the voice for Paddington in the theatrical films. ( ) This is the perfect double feature to keep the family enthralled and happy for at least three hours. Paddington could have been a capitalisation of a beloved brand, but it resulted in a sweet, smart, heartwarming adaptation under the deft guidance of director and co-writer Paul King (also the director behind all of The Mighty Boosh). Then, against all the traditional sequel expectations, King went and one-upped himself with Paddington 2, due to the inclusion of the ultimate cartoon villain and Paddington foil, Phoenix Buchanan (Hugh Grant, in one of his finest performances). For a couple of years, Paddington 2 was the most positively reviewed film on Rotten Tomatoes — ranking even higher than revered films like Citizen Kane. So really, you're doing yourself and your family a favour by appreciating these modern classics. Trailer Where to watch: iview Gremlins The mogwai of 1984 Christmas horror/comedy Gremlins may look cute... but don't feed them after midnight! ( ) If you have a sprog that's ready to dip their toe into the world of horror, then look no further than this 80s classic. Helmed by legendary director Chris Columbus (Home Alone, Harry Potter 1 & 2), Gremlins sees a dad give his kid a mysterious furry friend for Christmas. Mogwais are cute and cuddly but break one of their rules of care and watch them turn into scaly monsters. With just the right amount of fright to ignite the fire of any young horror lover, you don't have to wait until the festive season to tear into Gremlins. Trailer Where to watch: SBSonDemand

Comedy

Your Monster Film still from Your Monster (2024) featuring Tommy Dewey ( ) From fishmen to zombies, women have been falling in love with film "monsters" for decades but none of them have been quite as fun and cathartic as Caroline Lindy's Your Monster. Timid Laura (Melissa Barrera) is forced to move back to her childhood home following a cancer diagnosis and a brutal, mid-treatment dumping from her dirtbag director boyfriend. Upon her return, she discovers Monster (Tommy Dewey, plastered in prosthetics) is taking up residence in the closet. Instead of devouring her whole, Monster teaches Laura how to harness her anger and their relationship turns romantic. Electrified by Barrera's stand-out performance, Your Monster is the Beauty and the Beast re-telling you never knew you needed. Trailer Where to watch: SBSonDemand Game Night Jason Bateman and Rachel McAdams in Game Night ( ) This 2018 gem suffers from bad title syndrome, as Game Night doesn't accurately describe the twisty hijinks that are expertly executed by directors John Francis Daley and Jonathan Goldstein. Max (Jason Bateman) and Annie (Rachel McAdams) are a couple connected by their love of charades and trivia. Their game night group is thrown into disarray when a treasure hunt created by Max's showboating brother goes awry. There are lots of incredible comedic performances but Jesse Plemons, more recognisable for his dramatic work in films like Alex Garland's Civil War, absolutely runs away with the show as monotonous cop, Gary. Trailer Where to watch: iview Ghosts The cast of UK sitcom Ghosts. ( ) This UK sitcom is such a winner that it's been replicated in five different countries (including an Australian version to be released very soon!). After a donk on the head, Alison (Charlotte Ritchie) is able to see the many ghosts that haunt her recently inherited country mansion — and the ghosts are just so excited to have someone new to talk to. Created by and starring comedy collective Them There (you might know them as the team behind Horrible Histories), Ghosts is one of the finest ensemble casts of the 21st century, just don't be surprised if you shed a few sentimental tears between the roaring laughter. Trailer Where to watch: iview

Australian

Sweetie Karen Colston in Jane Campion's debut feature film Sweetie. ( ) Anyone who has had to overcome extreme frustration to keep the family unit chugging along will relate to the interpersonal drama in Sweetie. When Dawn, nicknamed somewhat sarcastically by her family as Sweetie, returns home, her mother, father and sister's lives are thrown even more into dysfunction as they attempt to placate Sweetie's swinging outbursts. Jane Campion's debut feature sets in motion the New Zealand filmmaker's focus on complex and misunderstood female protagonists. It's thrilling to see Campion's mysterious and sometimes surreal visual taste, which would see her win two Oscars, bubble through in her first stab at a feature film. Trailer Where to watch: iview Big Backyard Quiz Hosts and contestants on Big Backyard Quiz ( ) Gather the fam, there's a FULL 10-EPISODE season of Big Backyard Quiz to spark the competitive urges. Following on from the last year's delightful NITV special, BBQ is expertly helmed by presenter Narelda Jacobs and comedian/poet Steven Oliver who crackle wonderfully together as co-hosts. A revolving door of Australia's best comedians, actors and artists are put to the test on their knowledge on First Nation's history and food in between interactive games. Two teams are captained by Indigenous stars like Shari Sebbens, Dave Woodhead and even Ernie Dingo, allowing for some hilarious back and forth between the hosts and the non-Indigenous contestants. Funny AND educational, what more could you want? Trailer Where to watch: SBSonDemand Sweat Heath Ledger in Sweat ( ) Can we interest you in a little hardcore Australian nostalgia courtesy of one-season-wonder sports drama Sweat? Over 26 episodes, viewers are invited into the high-pressure world of Sports West Academy, an extremely competitive school for the most talented burgeoning athletic stars. The full season is very consumable in a binge-watch format due to the combination of hot people and soap opera-level drama. But the real hook is getting to watch a then-unknown teenage Heath Ledger act his little heart out as country-boy cyclist Snowy Bowles (yes, really), who must grapple with coming out to his teammates. Filmed in and around some of Perth's most recognisable landmarks, Sweat harks back to the golden days of Australian teen melodrama. Trailer Where to watch: Brollie

Surprise me

title: Small bull rider with a 'big heart' takes on the world's best
text:
In a huge dark hat and shining belt buckle, this 10-year-old kid from Kowanyama knows what he loves.

From one of Queensland's most remote towns, on the west coast of Cape York, Carl Douglas Jr has heard the enticing roar of a rodeo crowd in Utah in the west of the United States.

The pint-sized champion loves riding mini bulls, and he can now say he has done it in front of the world.

Starting in the sport only two years ago, he quickly proved himself a talent in the ring, winning medals around the Queensland circuit.

Carl placed third in the junior IMBA World Finals and seventh overall. (Supplied: Curtis Jensen, Bullseye Imaging)

It was at one of these regional rodeos that Carl was spotted and chosen to represent Australia on the global stage at the International Mini Bull Riding Association World Finals.

With the support of his town, Carl and his parents made the long journey from their home, 600 kilometres north-west of Cairns, to Utah earlier this month.

His father, Carl Douglas Snr, was a bronco rider himself back in the day, and said it was an incredible experience not just for his family but for the eight other children chosen to compete from across the country.

"In Australia it's small, but when you get over there on the other side of the world, the things are bigger, there's more riders … it was eye-catching," he said.

Loading...

'He can ride these American bulls'

Carl Jr is a softly spoken but confident boy who knows just what pose to strike with his cowboy shirt and shades.

He said the US rodeo scene was "strange" to him, but he still found it easy to focus.

Carl's parents, Valma Beatrice Lawrence and Carl Douglas Snr, travelled with him to Utah. (ABC Far North: Holly Richardson)

"Much more crowded and more riders," he said.

" [I] could feel everybody shouting. "

His mother, Valma Beatrice Lawrence, said despite watching Carl Jr enter the ring many times, the American bulls made her nervous.

"My heart was pounding and I didn't know what to do and I just sort of sat there and I prayed for him while I was sitting there," she said.

"Then when I saw him come out on this bull, I thought, 'Oh, he can ride these American bulls', and he did … he did really well."

Carl placed third in the International Mini Bull Riding Association's junior finals and seventh overall.

Carl was one of nine Australian children who travelled to Utah to compete. (ABC Far North: Holly Richardson)

Jumping on with a big heart

The love of the sport also bonded Carl with other kids from around the world.

"It was something very special for us to see, and it was heart-touching," Ms Lawrence said.

She said the kids would see each other every day and share yarns about bulls and life back home.

The Kowanyama community threw a welcome-home parade for Carl. (Supplied: Kowanyama Council)

Aside from the rides and games at the championship, Carl Jr said meeting the other competitors and building his passion for the sport were highlights on the trip.

"I felt good, just got to focus on riding and jump on with a big heart," he said.

"I told them I was from Australia and I'm a bull rider … I love riding bulls."

When he returned to Kowanyama, his hometown put on a welcome parade.

And Carl is already looking forward to the next time he is back in the ring.

"I'll do it for the rest of my life."

title: Oasis's 'biblical' reunion is largely thanks to this blockbuster album
text:
Unless this is your first day on the internet, you've no doubt noticed Britpop-era icons Oasis are back together, playing their first shows in 16 years.

The tour has already netted an estimated £400 million ($815 million) before arriving in Australia in late October.

Contemporaries like Blur, Pulp, Suede, and Supergrass have all experienced their own revivals or remained active, but few seem to have captured the current moment quite like Oasis.

"Biblical", as the band and their fans would put it.

It is a successful comeback that has drawn much excitement. But also, derision.

Reappraisal of Oasis's legacy has caused some to wonder if they were really all that great to begin with, largely amounting to 'What if The Beatles were football hooligans?'

An op-ed in The Guardian called them "the most damaging pop cultural force in recent British history", blaming the Gallagher brothers' "knuckle-dragging ideas on sexuality and politics" for the crime of setting back social attitudes, presaging Brexit and conservative nationalism.

The Gallagher brothers at the first Oasis reunion concert on Friday, July 4, 2025, in Cardiff. (AP: Scott A Garfitt/Invision )

Indeed, the brothers' droll, foul-mouthed way with words was glamorised by tabloids, earning a reputation as large as their chart-busting songs that helped define the '90s.

Of all the reasons people are so ecstatic about an Oasis reunion, a good number of them can be found on the group's best-selling second album, (What's The Story) Morning Glory?, released 30 years ago this week.

There is, of course, the inescapable Wonderwall, the epic Champagne Supernova, the swaggering Roll With It, and swooning Don't Look Back In Anger — an instant classic inspired by a snippet of John Lennon conversation and a nod to his famous solo single.

"Aren't those two chords the same as Imagine? No shit," Noel Gallagher once remarked, engaged in a mock exchange with an imaginary cynic.

" 'You can't do that!?' I can and I will. And I have. And you'll buy it, so f*** off. "

Love him or loathe him, he was absolutely right.

A Britpop blockbuster

Despite a muted reaction from the music press, decrying the follow-up to 1994's raw debut Definitely Maybe as generic, laddish, lazy, and "phoney Beatlemania", Morning Glory was hugely popular.

It wasn't just a hit. It was the fastest-selling album in the UK since Michael Jackson's Bad, eventually shifting more than 23 million copies worldwide.

"There was that moment where … we were number one in the singles [and] albums charts, consecutively for weeks," said Noel Gallagher.

" That was the kind of shit I dreamt about when I was at school, do you know what I mean? "

Oasis's Noel Gallagher performing live in front of 40,000 fans on April 27, 1996, in Manchester. (Reuters)

The album spent five weeks atop the Australian charts and has since gone eight-times Platinum, its influence audible in Australian acts ranging from Jet and The Superjesus to DMA'S and Middle Kids.

"Nobody had any f***ing idea what was going to happen. I wrote the songs; I was more surprised than anyone," remarked Gallagher.

"I've said it many, many times, but if I had known then what I know now about just what Wonderwall would become, or Don't Look Back In Anger, I'd never finish those songs. I'd still be fiddling around with it."

If anything, the guitarist-songwriter was anticipating a poor reception from critics, who chastised the pivot towards beer-y balladry and big, pop-friendly choruses.

" It didn't get one good review … We were kind of waiting for that because most people, our record company included, were expecting Definitely Maybe Part Two. "

The outcome was an added surprise for British media, who only a few months earlier had fuelled a rivalry between Oasis and Blur, capitalising on 'Cool Britannia' and updating the 'Rolling Stones vs Beatles' chart face-off for the '90s.

Dubbed the 'Battle of Britpop', it saw London's artsy, middle-class Blur pitted against Manchester's working-class Gallagher brothers, each releasing singles from their respective upcoming albums on the same day: August 14, 1995.

Blur's Country House would beat Roll With It to number one. Oasis may have lost the battle, but (What's The Story) Morning Glory? won them the war.

Bigger and better

Definitely Maybe introduced Oasis as the most exciting British band of the '90s, a Manchester quintet using rock'n'roll as their ticket out of their ordinary existence.

(What's The Story) Morning Glory? made them massive worldwide. An unapologetic pitch for global domination stocked with stadium-sized anthems with mass appeal that drew on familiar sources.

As Gallagher noted in a 1996 interview with Rolling Stone:

" The first album is about dreaming of being a pop star in a band. The second album is about actually being a pop star in a band. "

Morning Glory has the vitality and attitude of its predecessor, but the gestures are grander, with a wide-screen sonic sensibility that capitalised on Noel Gallagher's blossoming abilities as a songwriter, expanding into more intricate arrangements and surprisingly sensitive territory.

The melancholy Cast No Shadow features some of his most elegant and vulnerable lyrics, inspired by The Verve's Richard Ashcroft (who opened Oasis's comeback shows in the UK and Ireland) and riffing on chords from Pink Floyd's Wish You Were Here.

The cello-assisted yearning of Wonderwall and piano-led Don't Look Back In Anger possessed a timeless quality. Sure enough, 30 years on, they're both deathless hits.

Loading Instagram content

Beyond the over-saturated singles, the rest of Morning Glory can still thrill.

The title track is a reminder that Oasis could rock — a maelstrom of wailing guitars signalled by a helicopter before Liam Gallagher's delivery of one of the great couplets about cocaine power fantasies ever penned:

" All your dreams are made/When you're chained to the mirror and the razor blade. "

Roll With It and the whimsical She's Electric are perfect examples of Beatles songs "played with the attitude of The Rolling Stones and the volume of The Who," as ABC writer Matt Neal put it.

Meanwhile, The Jam frontman and Modfather himself, Paul Weller, played harmonica on the stormy Swamp Song instrumental interludes, and searing guitar histrionics on the epic curtain-closer Champagne Supernova.

"Thank God he did," Noel Gallagher reflected. "It was crying out for a guitar solo because mine was a shocker."

He had held a similarly self-deprecating streak towards his songwriting abilities.

"Everything that I do is a nod to something or other. I'm not a genius. I'm a fan of music. Paul McCartney's a genius, and Morrissey and Bob Dylan. I'm just fans of theirs.

" I've got a good knack of putting shit together but I'm not a snob about where it comes from. I'll tell you. Nothing is original, there's only 12 notes anyway. "

That self-awareness belies Gallagher's talent for siphoning decades of British rock fanaticism — from The Kinks through to The Smiths and The Stone Roses — into a proverbial sonic trifle that was at once familiar but boasted a distinctive flavour.

Sibling chemistry

Responding to his elder brother's growth, Liam Gallagher upped the ante on his already commanding vocal sneer.

Liam Gallagher's vocals were "f***ing on another level on that record," his brother Noel remarked in 2020. (Dave Hunt, file photo: AAP)

His instantly recognisable mix of unimpeachable bravado, charisma and yearning resulted in some of the most memorable rock vocal performances of his, or anyone's career.

Especially on Wonderwall, its name taken from a lesser-known George Harrison album and originally dedicated to Noel's ex-wife, Meg Matthews.

Who else could bring such conviction and sense of drama to lyrics whose own author was quick to dismiss as meaningless?

"You know, people have said that to me down the years, 'What does 'slowly walking down the hall faster than a cannonball mean?'" Noel Gallagher said in his Take 5 with Zan Rowe, illuminating an important comparison between Champagne Supernova and I Am The Walrus by The Beatles.

"I'm like 'take enough drugs you'll know what it means'. Sitting on a cornflake? Yeah, I've sat on many a cornflake."

Beyond the hedonism, Gallagher's songwriting is less about meaning than it is about mood and magnetic simplicity.

Loading Instagram content

Don't Look Back In Anger, Some Might Say, Wonderwall, Champagne Supernova — these songs feel pregnant with importance, even if ultimately, they're apocryphal.

They gesture at something thoughtful without being profound, which, for better or worse, has proven to resonate with a broad audience.

Just ask the band's resident 'man on the street', Liam Gallagher: the boorish, extroverted yin to Noel's relatively understated yang.

Despite their in-fighting, he clearly relished his elder brother's bar stool philosophy and bulletproof melodies that played to his strength as a vocalist.

Recording a classic

Having already recorded and released Some Might Say in April 1995 (which topped the charts months before the 'Battle of Britpop'), in May, Oasis decamped to Rockfield Studios, a former dairy farm situated in the Welsh countryside of Monmouth.

They were booked in for six weeks but ended up finishing the album in less than half that time.

"We worked hard. I think it was 12 business days," Noel Gallagher remembers.

He'd been boasting to journos as early as Definitely Maybe's release that he'd already written songs for a follow-up. In truth, there was the makings of half an album.

Oasis (from left): Liam Gallagher, Paul McGuigan, Paul "Bonehead" Arthurs, Alan White, Noel Gallagher in November 1995 outside Earls Court, London, touring (What's The Story) Morning Glory? (Oasis: Facebook)

"Half the songs have got a second verse — they were all written before I got [there]. And the rest of the songs, it's just the first verse twice," he recalls. "That was me getting in here and going 'oh well, f*** it'.

"You're just working on instinct because you don't second-guess anything when you're young."

That sense of vigour and audacious machismo was all over the album, which reunited the band with producer Owen Morris.

"In the first five days we'd recorded Roll With It, Hello, Wonderwall, Don't Look Back In Anger and Champagne Supernova," he told Q Magazine in 2011.

The most productive week in Britpop history?

Why we still love Wonderwall Photo shows Liam Gallagher looks at the camera in a black jacket A quarter century after its release, why does Wonderwall still speak to so many people?

A feat made more remarkable considering the band hit the decks only a week after recruiting drummer Alan White (replacing Tony McCarroll), who swiftly found his place in the group dynamic.

"I soon cottoned on," White told Q Magazine. "I was the Cockney c**t and they were the Manc f***ers. As a kind of family unit, it felt really good."

The same can't be said for the Gallaghers, whose infamous sibling rivalry inevitably reared its head and temporarily brought sessions to a grinding halt.

Whereas Noel was laser-focused on overcoming difficult second album syndrome, staying up late working on mixes, and nailing the perfect take, Liam would quickly hammer out his vocal takes and become bored.

"There was loads of pubs in town that we'd heard were good," he said in a 2020 Rockfield documentary.

" It was like 'get in there and f***in' smash it out and then f***in' pub'! "

The night that nearly broke Oasis

After one particularly heavy drinking excursion, Liam invited a 20-strong entourage — "a load of f***ing idiots back from the local village," according to Noel — for a party back at the studio's on-site accommodation.

That included members of British grunge band Cable, who began winding Liam up. Things turned sour, and drunken fisticuffs ensued, which only escalated once Noel returned from recording to the scene.

Liam remembers his brother's fury: "'What you doing bringing people back when we're working?!' And I get it but …

"My argument would be: What are you doing f***ing taking 900 f***ing takes to f***ing do one guitar when you should be in the f***ing pub with me? You know what I mean? Entertaining me?"

The ensuing brawl involved air rifles, a cricket bat, a tossed rubbish bin, £800 in property damage, and Liam shouting obscenities after Noel as White drove him back to London.

The future of the band, let alone the album, was uncertain.

"Me and our kid [Noel] had a bit of a scuffle," Gallagher junior told Q Magazine in 2011.

"I went home with a broken arm, broken leg and a shotgun on me shoulder, and me mum goes 'What kind of f***in' music are you making down there!?'

The brothers didn't show up at the studio the following week.

"People felt they might not finish the album, for sure," Oasis photographer Michael Spencer Jones told BBC. "It was a serious falling out … on another level."

It's widely regarded as one of the worst conflicts in a very long list of volcanic Gallagher clashes.

But that same tension is deeply intertwined with what many consider Oasis's finest musical hour, a toxic chemistry that's, weirdly, also a winning formula.

"That's the story of the band's life really. It'd sort of be good one minute and then it'd be chaotic the next," says Liam.

After almost 10 days, and some delicate behind-the-scenes diplomacy, the Gallaghers decided not to look back in anger.

The band reconvened at Rockfield and finished off recording She's Electric, Cast No Shadow, Hey Now, and Morning Glory.

"That second session was the best, easiest, least fraught, most happily creative time I've ever had in a recording studio," Morris recalled.

Noel Gallagher was "furious" when he first saw the cover for (What's The Story) Morning Glory? It was shot in London's Berwick Street. (Oasis: Michael Spencer Jones)

Oasis ended up having songs to spare, recording several B-sides that — in Noel Gallagher's own estimation — were "good enough to launch any band's career."

Acquiesce, Talk Tonight, Headshrinker, Rockin' Chair, Underneath The Sky, and The Masterplan: all fan favourites that featured on a compilation, also titled The Masterplan, that many consider ranks alongside the first two studio albums as Oasis's best work.

In retrospect, Gallagher believes it was his most fruitful creative period.

"The Masterplan' might've been the last of the f***in' great culturally significant songs that I wrote," he said in 2020.

Live forever

In 1996, Oasis headlined two historic concerts at Knebworth, England, to more than 250,000 fans — some of the biggest concerts in British history.

" Nothing was ever the same after that," remarks Gallagher. "Then the money came in and all f***ing hell broke loose. "

Be Here Now, the band's third album, was released in August 1997 to rave reviews (from critics who'd learned to save face after slagging off its predecessor). It became Britain's fastest-selling album ever, but swiftly denounced as a disappointment.

The long, indulgent "sound of five men in the studio, on coke, not giving a f***," as Noel Gallagher put it in the 2003 Britpop documentary Live Forever.

Loading...

Liam, on the other hand, thought "it was f***ing great, and I still think it's great. It just wasn't Morning Glory."

Indeed. Be Here Now was considered rock-bottom because Morning Glory is credited as being Britpop's pinnacle, the barometer by which Oasis was subsequently measured.

Their 2000s records contained flashes of brilliance but began to sound tired, bloated, and struggling to reach the rarefied heights of their earlier output.

Oasis always acted as if they were invincible, but (What's The Story) Morning Glory? marked the point they were legitimately unstoppable.

"We'd made it, we got to the top of the mountain and we were treated like The Jam and The Beatles," reflected Gallagher.

Now, 30 years later, Oasis is enjoying the fairytale rock narrative the Fab Four never got to: the reunion.

As polarising as the Gallaghers and their graceless public personas could be, the music they made as Oasis possessed a magnetism that brought audiences together.

Just ask the social media users sharing in the opposite of Schadenfreude in seeing the long-feuding Gallaghers seemingly enjoying each other's company on stage again.

Witness the crowds of people singing along word for passionate word. And it isn't just aging Millennials in football jerseys and bucket hats but younger fans belting out classics that have outlived their '90s origins.

Is this collective evidence that Oasis really is the long-touted 'People's Band' after all? Not maybe. Definitely.

"The people that made [the greatest] records, they're not making them for journalists," Noel Gallagher remarked around Morning Glory's 25th anniversary.

"They're making them for the people, and the people decide what's hot [and] what is not. And that's it, the end."

Listen to Double J's Classic Albums for more stories behind the best records of all time.

title: Aussies ice World Para Swimming Championships with relay gold
text:
Australia has claimed its ninth gold medal at the World Para Swimming Championships on the final day of competition in Singapore.

Lex Leary, Rowan Crothers, Chloe Osborn and Callum Simpson teamed up to claim victory in the mixed 4x100 metres freestyle relay (34 points), setting a world record in the process.

The Australian quartet stopped the clock in 3 minutes and 58.40 seconds, finishing ahead of China and France.

The triumph meant Australia claimed 26 medals across the world titles, having also won nine silver and eight bronze medals.

Australia finished seventh on the medal tally.

"Singapore was a successful campaign, especially by our measure of success for individual performance," Australia's head coach, Mel Tantrum, said.

"In comparison, Manchester 2023 was our most successful world champs campaign in a decade, in terms of individual gold medals with eight, and we have equalled that.

"We have a good mix of youth and experience, and our performance measures are being met."

Australia also won three silver medals and a bronze on the final day of competition.

Leary and Osborn finished second in the respective women's 50m (S9) and 100m freestyle (S7) events, while Thomas Gallagher was runner-up in the men's 100m backstroke (S10).

Rachael Watson collected the bronze in the women's 100m freestyle (S3).

Simpson left the meet with three golds, one silver, and a bronze.

title: Snow town struggles as high housing prices force residents out
text:
Charlie Steinbacher knows how his town changes in winter, when crowds of avid snow goers flock to the ski slopes.

"Winter versus summer is like chalk and cheese," the born-and-raised Jindabyne resident said.

" Our population grows almost tenfold. "

Jindabyne is the base town of the New South Wales ski resorts.

It has a population of about 4,000 people but explodes with tourists during winter.

Most of the tourists travelling to Jindabyne are chasing the snow season. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

More than 380,000 people travelled to the Snowy Mountains region between July and September in 2024 alone, according to Destination NSW.

About one-quarter of Jindabyne's 2,900 homes are short-term rental accommodation.

Mr Steinbacher, who runs an indoor rock-climbing business in Jindabyne, said he had been priced out of town.

Charlie Steinbacher says the dream of owning a home is challenging to achieve. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

"Everyone would love to own a home in Jindabyne where we all grew up, but it's just not really viable," he said.

" There's a lot of houses that just sit vacant for most of the year because they can make so much money through the winter. "

Locals priced out

Mr Steinbacher moved to Berridale, 30 minutes away, last year, joining a cohort of young locals.

The average house in Jindabyne is on the market for more than $1.1 million and median unit rents have increased by nearly 85 per cent in the past five years.

The median house price has increased by $300,000 since 2020 and is now double that of 15 years ago, according to housing data analysts Cotality.

Unit prices have nearly tripled since 2010.

Nancy Gant-Thompson has lived in Jindabyne since the 1980s. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

Nancy Gant-Thompson owns her home but hosts a ski instructor as a boarder each winter to afford heating.

"I really couldn't survive winter here if I didn't have some additional income," she said.

"It's either a choice of downsizing … or sharing your accommodation and your home with people."

Nancy Gant-Thompson takes on a boarder every winter to afford to heat her home. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

Ms Gant-Thompson said she knew of many older people who moved to Canberra because of Jindabyne's high prices.

It is a regular source of conversation at Country Women's Association meetings.

"There's not a lot of places available for rent," member Dale Whitfield said.

" I know there's quite a lot of families whose kids have had to move away from the area. "

Dale Whitfield and Toni Clarke talk about housing struggles at the CWA. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

The NSW government announced in 2019 that it would create the Snowy Mountains Special Activation Precinct, a 40-year plan to grow year-round tourism and housing stock in the region.

The Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development told the ABC the government acquired land in Jindabyne near the Southern Connector Road corridor in 2024 that could "offer an additional 500 dwellings" over the next 20 years.

It said the "masterplan" for the future of Jindabyne would aim "to increase the variety of housing available" and improve supply and affordability.

Short-term rental review

The state government is reviewing short-term rental accommodation.

Snowy Monaro Regional Council made a submission to the review, raising concerns about the impacts of short-term rentals on housing affordability but noting tourism benefits.

"It is essential for the continued growth and vitality of the town that Jindabyne continues to provide tourist accommodation," the council submission read.

Jindabyne has one of the highest rates of short-term rentals in NSW. (ABC South East NSW: Floss Adams)

The government said it was investigating the submissions ahead of proposing sector reforms.

It comes a year after it implemented a 60-day cap on short-term rentals in Byron Bay to increase the supply of long-term rentals.
